chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: The last type of operator we will talk about is the assignment operator.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We have seen one type of assignment operator, now let's see the other types of assignment operator.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Assignment operator is basically, if I write A is equal to B,

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: then Java will assign the value of the operator you have written in the right to the left.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And this equal to, we will call it the assignment operator.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So first of all, we have the assignment operator equal to.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: As soon as I write A equal to B, then the value of B will come in my A.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If the value of B is 5, then if the value of A was 10, then it will be cut and its value will also become 5 in the memory.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We have seen this many times so far.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: But this time we will explore a different variation of the assignment operator.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I have to write A is equal to A plus 10 or B is equal to B minus 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So I can write this statement as A plus equal to 10.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And I can change this statement to B minus equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So this is just a small way to write the same assignment, wherever the assignment comes.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And the operand remains the same.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Only one variable value comes, so there we can write plus equal to.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And where something is being minused from the same operand, something is being minused from the same variable and the same variable is being assigned.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So there we can write B minus is equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If we have any variable int A is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And if I have to print system.out.println, this A.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: I just have to change its value a little.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I write A is equal to A plus 10.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So what will happen in this case?

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: My A will be printed for me like 20.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: But if I write this here, comment.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And here I write plus equal to 10.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So in this case also Java will return me the same output which is 20.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So there is no difference between this statement and this statement.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: In fact, if I tell you, this statement will be executed faster.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Java will execute it with more speed.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: This speed will be much faster in execution in nanoseconds.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: That's why we won't see it now.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: But if you write big programs, do competitive programming, write big codes for your interviews or for your coding test.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So it is advisable to write this statement instead of this statement.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So it will give you faster execution.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Apart from that, let's check another variation.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Int B is equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Now if I have to do B is equal to B minus 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So I know what value it will give.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I want to print the value of final B.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So I will get 0 after printing.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: But if I change this statement and write B minus equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: And then I print B.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So in that case I will get 0.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So there is no difference between this statement and this statement.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: These two statements are same.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: In fact, the meaning is same but this statement is a little bit faster.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Similarly, we can write plus equal to or minus equal to.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Similarly, we can multiply and divide.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I multiply this, then what will happen?

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: In that case, it will mean B is equal to.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: I will erase all this so that it is understood properly.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: I took integer B is equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So I wrote B multiplied equal to 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So it means B is equal to B multiplied by 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: 5 multiplied by 5 is 25.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So finally it is 25.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I divide here.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Like I did here.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So it means B is equal to B divided by 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Which will give me 1.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We can also modulo this.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We can also remove the remainder.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: If I divide 5 by 5.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: Then the remainder will be 0.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So the final output is 0.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: So we have covered all the assignment operators.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: In the day to day, we will be writing different codes.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We will be writing different programs.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: We will be building up a lot of logic.

chunks.title: Assignment
chunks.text: In those codes, we will be using all these operators one by one.

Assignment operator is basically, if I write A is equal to B, then Java will assign the value of the operator you have written in the right to the left. But this time we will explore a different variation of the assignment operator. If I have to write A is equal to A plus 10 or B is equal to B minus 5. So I can write this statement as A plus equal to 10. And I can change this statement to B minus equal to 5. So this is just a small way to write the same assignment, wherever the assignment comes. And the operand remains the same. Only one variable value comes, so there we can write plus equal to. And where something is being minused from the same operand, something is being minused from the same variable and the same variable is being assigned. So there we can write B minus is equal to 5. If we have any variable int A is equal to 10. And if I have to print system.out.println, this A. I just have to change its value a little. If I write A is equal to A plus 10. So what will happen in this case? My A will be printed for me like 20. But if I write this here, comment. And here I write plus equal to 10. So in this case also Java will return me the same output which is 20. So there is no difference between this statement and this statement. In fact, if I tell you, this statement will be executed faster. Java will execute it with more speed. This speed will be much faster in execution in nanoseconds. That's why we won't see it now. If I want to print the value of final B. So I will get 0 after printing. But if I change this statement and write B minus equal to 5. And then I print B. So in that case I will get 0. Similarly, we can write plus equal to or minus equal to. Similarly, we can multiply and divide. If I multiply this, then what will happen? In that case, it will mean B is equal to.
